Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They plan to spend the day lounging at home with immediate family.
Story:
I sat at my desk, laptop open, blueprints scattered around me. The project manager’s email blinked on my screen: “We need a working prototype by tomorrow. Stakeholders want to see progress before they approve funding.” My mind raced with technical possibilities, but I was still in my pajamas—loose and comfortable, perfect for a day at home with my family. I hadn’t planned to see anyone outside, so I hadn’t changed into my usual modest attire. 

But then, a video call notification popped up. The team wanted to discuss the prototype, and the stakeholders might join. I felt a knot in my stomach. As an engineer, I was expected to be ready, professional, and responsive, especially now. But as a Muslim, I was also expected to dress modestly, even in virtual meetings, out of respect for my values. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount. Should I rush to change, risking being late and unprepared, or join as I was, compromising my beliefs? My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pulling me in opposite directions.
